imports: from game_logic.characters import Client, Reader, Nyx

content.value: Rain hammers against your apartment window. It's been raining for three days straight—typical for October in the Pacific Northwest. The kind of rain that makes everything feel muted, like the world is wrapped in wet cotton.

You're sitting at your kitchen table, nursing a cup of coffee that went cold an hour ago. Bills are spread out in front of you. Rent's due in a week. Your phone screen glows with job listings that all require "3-5 years experience" for positions that pay barely above minimum wage.
Outside, a delivery truck splashes through a puddle. Brakes squeal.

text.value: Someone's at the door, I may as well answer it

content.value: You trudge to the door, still in the sweatpants you've been wearing for two days.
The delivery driver is already halfway back to their truck, umbrella barely keeping them dry. On your doorstep: a small package, brown paper wrapping, no return address.
You bring it inside, water dripping onto your floor.
You stay at the table. Probably just more junk mail anyway.
You haul yourself to the door, irritated now. By the time you open it, the delivery driver is gone. Just a package on your step, brown paper already soaking through.
You grab it before it gets completely drenched.
You set it on the table, pushing bills aside.
You drop it on the table with a wet thud, scattering bills.

No return address. No shipping label. Just your name and address, handwritten in dark ink. The handwriting is old-fashioned—elegant loops and careful spacing. The kind of penmanship your grandmother might have had.

text.value: Check for a return address first

content.value: Curiosity wins. You tear the paper, not bothering with scissors.
Inside: a small black leather book, about the size of a paperback. The cover is worn smooth, corners soft from handling. No title. No markings.
And underneath it, folded carefully: a letter.
Your hands are shaking slightly as you unfold it.
You turn it over, looking for any clue about who sent this.
Nothing. Just that careful handwriting. Your name. Your address.
You get scissors from the kitchen drawer and cut the tape methodically. Fold back the paper.
Inside: a small black leather book and a folded letter.
The book looks old. Well-loved. The leather is soft, darkened with age.
You pick up the letter first.
You've got bills to worry about. Job applications to send. Real life doesn't stop for mysterious packages.
But your eyes keep drifting back to it.
After ten minutes, you give in and open it.
Inside: a small black leather book and a letter.
The letter is written on thick cream paper, the same elegant handwriting:
*I don't know you, not personally. But the cards know you. They've been waiting.*
*I'm done. My time as a reader has passed. These clients need someone new—someone with fresh eyes and an open heart. Someone who hasn't grown tired yet.*
*The book contains names. People I've read for over the years. Some of them have been with me for decades. Some are new. All of them need guidance.*
*They're yours now, if you want them.*
*The cards will show you the way. They always do.*
*P.S. Get some sleep -- you'll need it.*

text.value: Check the package again for any other clues
This is some kind of prank

content.value: You set the letter down and pick up the book.
The leather is cool under your fingers. Smooth. There's something almost alive about it—like it's been held so many times, by so many hands, that it's absorbed their warmth.
Names. Dozens of them. Hundreds, maybe. Each entry written in that same careful hand:
*Chen, Margaret - First reading: March 1987. Comes monthly. Prefers Celtic Cross. Brings tea.*
*Patterson, James - First reading: June 1989. Career concerns. Skeptical but returns.*
*Valdez, Sofia - First reading: April 2003. Grief reading. Lost her sister. Sensitive.*
*Morrison, Grant - First reading: January 2020. Relationship troubles. Talks too much. Means well.*
Lives documented. Problems recorded. Observations noted.
The last entry is dated three weeks ago.
Your hands are really shaking now.
You tear apart the wrapping paper, looking for any other information.
Nothing. No note. No business card. No return address label that peeled off.
Just the book and the letter.
This has to be a prank. Or a scam. Or-
But even as you think it, you know it's not true.
Nobody would go to this much trouble for a prank. And what kind of scam involves giving you something instead of asking for money?
You flip through the pages, heart pounding.
This is a client list. An actual, real client list for a tarot reading practice that's been running for nearly four decades.
And someone just... gave it to you.
*How did you even end up here? How did you become someone who reads tarot cards?*

text.value: You learned from your grandmother. This is a family tradition.
You were a therapist who started using tarot with clients. You recently quit to do this full-time.
You taught yourself from books and online videos. You're still learning.
The cards just... started speaking to you one day. You don't fully understand it yourself.

content.value: She'd taught you when you were twelve, her wrinkled hands guiding yours as you shuffled her deck—the same deck her grandmother had given her. Rider-Waite-Smith, so old the edges were soft as fabric.
She'd made you memorize the cards. Every symbol. Every traditional meaning. The way the Fool's journey mirrored life itself.
"The cards are older than you think," she'd said. "And they remember. They always remember."
She died six months ago. Pneumonia, quick and cruel. You'd inherited her deck, her books, her small collection of crystals she'd never actually believed in but kept anyway "for the aesthetics."
You'd done readings for friends. For family. Small things. You never charged money—that felt wrong somehow, like you'd be profiting off Grandma's memory.
But now rent is due and your savings are running out and you've been thinking, lately, that maybe...
You look at the letter again. The initial: *M*.
But the handwriting isn't hers. You'd know her loops anywhere—she always made her Rs look like Bs.
Thorne isn't your grandmother's last name. But the coincidence makes your skin prickle.
Licensed Clinical Social Worker. Master's degree. Three years in community mental health, another two in private practice. You were good at it. You helped people.
But insurance companies dictated treatment. Six sessions maximum. Evidence-based interventions only. No time for the kind of deep, transformational work that actually helped people heal.
Then a client—a woman dealing with a difficult divorce—brought in her tarot deck one session. "Would it be weird if I pulled a card?" she asked. "It helps me think."

And something about the image—lightning striking, figures falling, old structures collapsing—gave her permission to say what she'd been unable to say: that her marriage had been a prison. That she was terrified of freedom. That she didn't know who she was without someone else defining her.
The card was just a picture. But it opened something.
You started bringing cards to sessions. Just as a tool. A projective technique. Clients loved them.
Three months ago, you quit therapy to do tarot full-time.
Your colleagues thought you'd lost your mind.
Your bank account agreed with them.
But you believed in it. You still do.
No mystical inheritance. No professional training. Just curiosity and YouTube videos and a used tarot deck from a thrift store.

You'd been going through a rough patch—breakup, lost job, the usual quarter-life crisis stuff—and a friend suggested trying tarot. "It's not about predicting the future," they said. "It's about reflection."
So you bought a deck. Started reading. Fell down the rabbit hole of tarot blogs and podcasts and online courses.
At first, you read for yourself. Then for friends. Then—tentatively—you started charging for readings. Not much. Twenty dollars. Then thirty. Then fifty.
You're still learning. Still figuring out your style. Still looking up card meanings sometimes when you're not sure.
That has to mean something, right?
The cards just... started speaking to you.
You don't know how else to describe it.
It was about a year ago. You were at a friend's birthday party—one of those "mystical experience" parties where everyone gets drunk and plays with an old Ouija board ironically.
You'd picked up the deck, shuffling absently, and suddenly—
Not thoughts, exactly. Not voices. Just... knowing. Like the cards were whispering their meanings directly into your consciousness. Images appearing fully formed in your mind.

The Three of Swords wasn't just heartbreak. It was specifically your friend Sarah's heartbreak over her recent divorce. The Tower wasn't just upheaval. It was Marcus's impending job loss (which happened two weeks later).
You told them what you saw.
Now you do readings regularly. You still don't fully understand it. You don't know why the cards speak to you. You don't know how this works.
Your phone shows three missed calls.
"Hello, this is Margaret Chen calling for M. Thorne. I have my regular appointment next Thursday at 2 PM? Please call me back to confirm. Thank you."
The first name in the book.
"Hi, uh, I'm trying to reach M. Thorne? My name is Sarah Kim and I was referred by my coworker. I'd really like to schedule a reading. This week if possible. Call me back?"
"M., it's James. I know you said you were wrapping up your practice, but I really need to talk. Things at work are... well. You know. Call me when you can."
These people are expecting M. Thorne.
You look at your phone. Two missed calls from unknown numbers.
You listen to the first one:
"Hello, this is calling for M. Thorne. My name is Patricia Wells. I've been seeing M. for about five years now, and I'd like to schedule my next appointment. Please call me back."
"Hi, M., it's Grant Morrison. Just wanted to confirm our Thursday appointment. Let me know if anything's changed."
These people are waiting for appointments with M. Thorne.
"This is a message for M. Thorne. My name is Elena Rodriguez and I was hoping to schedule a reading. My friend Sofia recommended you years ago. Please call back."
"M., it's Margaret Chen. I have my standing appointment next week. Just wanted to confirm you're still available."
"Hi, uh, I'm not sure if this is the right number. I'm looking for M. Thorne, the tarot reader. I really need a reading as soon as possible. Please call me."
These people don't know M. Thorne is gone.
The moment you think about checking voicemail, you know there will be messages waiting.
"Hello, M. Thorne? This is Margaret Chen. I have my monthly appointment next Thursday. Please confirm. Thank you."
"Hi, my name is Grant Morrison. I've been seeing M. for a few years. I'd like to schedule something for next week if possible?"
"M., it's James Patterson. Things are getting complicated at work again. I could really use your insight. Call me."
The cards didn't just bring you this book.

text.value: Look through the book more thoroughly first
Send an email to M. Thorne's client list explaining the situation

content.value: You dial before you can talk yourself out of it.
She picks up on the second ring.
"Hi, uh, Mrs. Chen? You left a voicemail about... about an appointment?"
"No. I'm not. I just—I received a package today. A book. With client information. And a letter saying..."
You trail off. How do you even explain this?
"M. gave you the practice," Mrs. Chen says. It's not a question.
"I... I think so? I don't know. I don't know who M. Thorne is. I don't know why they chose me. I just—"
"My grandmother taught me. She passed away six months ago. I've been doing readings since I was young, but nothing... nothing professional."
"I'm a therapist. Was a therapist. I started using tarot in sessions and then quit to do readings full-time. About six months ago."
"I taught myself. Books, online resources. I've been practicing for about two years, doing readings for friends and some clients, but I'm still learning."
"About a year. I know that's not long. I didn't plan this. The cards just... started speaking to me. I know that sounds—"
"M. wouldn't have chosen you if you weren't ready," Mrs. Chen interrupts, gentle but firm. "I've known them for thirty-eight years. They don't make mistakes about these things."
"I still have my appointment Thursday," she continues. "Two PM. Will you be ready?"

text.value: "I don't know if I can do this."
"Can you tell me more about M. Thorne first?"

content.value: "Yes," you say, surprising yourself with how steady your voice sounds. "I'll be ready."
"Good." You can hear the smile in her voice. "I'll bring tea, like always. M. never could get the tea quite right. Maybe you'll have better luck."
After you hang up, you sit at your table, staring at the black book.
Thursday. Two PM. Your first appointment with one of M. Thorne's longtime clients.
You pull your tarot deck closer, letting your fingers rest on the cards.

text.value: Just... sit with this for a moment

content.value: "I don't know if I can do this," you say quietly. "Mrs. Chen, you've been with M. Thorne for thirty-eight years. What if I'm not... what if I can't—"

"Child," she interrupts, and there's such warmth in her voice it makes your eyes sting. "M. Thorne was terrified their first time too. I was their very first client, you know. March 1987. They were shaking so hard they dropped the cards twice."
"Really. But they read for me anyway. And it helped. It truly helped. That's all any of us can do—show up and try to help."
"I know you can. Thursday, 2 PM. I'll bring tea."
After she hangs up, you stare at the phone for a long moment.
Then you look at your tarot deck, sitting in its usual spot.
Show up and try to help.
"Can you tell me about M. Thorne?" you ask. "Who are they? Why did they stop? Why did they choose me?"
Mrs. Chen is quiet for a moment.

"M. is... private. Always has been. I've seen them once a month for thirty-eight years and I still don't know their first name. They liked it that way—keeping the focus on the cards, on the reading, not on themselves."
"They said they were tired. That they'd given all they could give, and it was time to pass it on. I asked them how they'd choose a successor. They said the cards would know."
You look at the letter again. *"But the cards know you. They've been waiting."*
"Neither do I, dear. Neither did M., I suspect. Sometimes we have to trust what we don't understand. Now, will you be there Thursday at 2 PM?"
"Good. I look forward to meeting you properly."
After you hang up, you sit in silence, the black book open in front of you.

text.value: You pull your deck toward you

content.value: You need to understand what you're dealing with before you call anyone back.
You flip through the black book slowly.

Hundreds of entries. Some clients saw M. Thorne once and never came back. Others have decades of appointments logged. Births. Deaths. Marriages. Divorces. All documented with clinical precision but also... care.
*Patterson, James - Career concerns. Skeptical but returns. Update: Promoted to director, June 1992. Still skeptical. Still returns.*
*Valdez, Sofia - Grief reading. Lost her sister. Update: Found peace through volunteer work with hospice. Reads annually now on her sister's birthday.*
*Morrison, Grant - Relationship troubles. Talks too much. Means well. Update: Married! Partner is patient. Good match. Still talks too much.*
These aren't just names and dates. These are lives. Stories. People M. Thorne cared about enough to remember, to track, to note.
And now you're supposed to care for them too.
You find yourself touching the pages gently, as if the book itself is alive.

text.value: Check your email—maybe there's more information

content.value: This is too big a decision to make alone.
You need to be transparent. Honest. These are M. Thorne's clients—people with established relationships, expectations. They deserve to know what's happening.
You open your laptop and start typing:
*You don't know me, but I received a package today containing M. Thorne's client registry and a letter explaining that they have retired from practice and have chosen me to continue their work.*
*I know this must come as a surprise. It surprised me too..."*
Too formal? Too casual? How do you even word this?

text.value: Send it as-is. Honesty is best.
Rewrite it. This needs to sound more professional.
Actually, maybe calling is better than email

content.value: You finish the email, keeping it simple and honest:

*"...I understand if you'd prefer to seek another reader. I also understand if you'd like to meet me first before deciding. And I certainly understand if you have questions about M. Thorne and why they made this choice.*
*If you'd like to continue your appointments with me, I'll do my very best to honor the trust M. Thorne placed in both of us.*
*Please feel free to contact me with any questions or concerns.*
You hit send before you can second-guess yourself.
Then you close the laptop and sit back, heart pounding.
There. Done. The truth is out there.

text.value: This is too much. Close the laptop.

content.value: You delete what you wrote and start over, more formal this time:
*This letter serves to inform you of a transition in M. Thorne's tarot reading practice. Effective immediately, M. Thorne has retired and transferred their client list to me.*
*M. Thorne has expressed confidence in my ability to serve your needs going forward. I am committed to maintaining the same level of care and insight you have come to expect.*
*Please contact me at your earliest convenience to schedule or reschedule appointments.*
It sounds... sterile. Professional, yes. But this doesn't feel right.
These people knew M. Thorne for years. Decades, some of them. They need warmth, not formality.

text.value: Send it anyway. Professional is good.
Delete it and start over with something more personal

content.value: This is too impersonal. These people deserve a phone call, not a mass email.
But the thought of calling dozens of strangers to explain this situation makes your stomach turn.

text.value: Call Mrs. Chen back. Start with one person.
This is too much. You need a minute.

content.value: M. Thorne must have a website, an email, something.
You search "M. Thorne tarot reader" and find it immediately: a simple, elegant website. Black background. Single page with a contact form and a brief description:
That's it. No photos. No biography. No testimonials.
You click on the email inbox—thankfully, the password was written on the inside back cover of the black book.
*"Hi M., it's David. Can we move my Thursday appointment to Friday?"*
*"Dear M. Thorne, I was referred by a friend. Do you have any openings this month?"*
*"M., it's been a rough week. Any chance you have time for an emergency reading?"*

text.value: Respond to the emails explaining the situation
This is too much. Close the laptop.

content.value: You can't just... inherit an entire tarot reading practice from someone you've never met. That's not how this works. That's not how anything works.
But the black book sits on your table.
The voicemail is still on your phone.
And somewhere, M. Thorne - whoever they are - thought you could handle this.

text.value: Call your best friend. You need to talk to someone normal.
Just... sit with this for a minute

content.value: You need to hear a familiar voice. Someone who knows you. Someone who will tell you if you're being completely delusional.
"Hey!" Your best friend answers on the second ring, sounding cheerful. "What's up? You never call during the day."
You explain the whole thing. The package. The letter. The black book full of clients. M. Thorne's mysterious retirement. The voicemails from people expecting appointments.
Your friend is quiet for a long moment.
"So you're telling me," they say slowly, "that a stranger just... mailed you an entire business? A tarot reading business with decades of clients? Just... here you go, it's yours now?"
"And you have no idea who this person is or why they chose you?"
"That's either the best thing that's ever happened to you or the beginning of a horror movie."
"Okay, real talk—what does your gut say? Not the cards, not logic. Just you. What do you feel about this?"
You look at the black book. The worn leather. The careful handwriting. The decades of care documented in those pages.
"My grandmother always said the cards call us when we're ready. Maybe... maybe this is my calling?"
"I quit therapy to do this work. To help people this way. Maybe this is the universe saying I made the right choice?"
"I've been trying to build a practice from scratch. This is... this is everything I've been working toward. Just handed to me."
"The cards brought me here. I don't understand why, but they always know what I need."
"Okay. Then do it. And call me after your first client so I know you haven't been murdered by a ghost tarot reader."
"I know. But seriously—if this feels right to you, trust it. You're good at this work. You help people. Maybe this M. Thorne person saw that somehow."
After you hang up, you feel steadier.
Your friend is right. You help people. That's what matters.

text.value: You reach for your tarot deck

content.value: You sit at the table, the black book open in front of you, and try to breathe.
Rain still hammering the windows. Coffee still cold. Bills still due.
But now this. This impossible gift. This mystery.
And what did they mean: *"Get some sleep"*?
When you read tarot—when you're sitting across from someone and the cards are laid out—how do you approach it? What's your process?

text.value: You trust your intuition. You feel what the cards are trying to say.
You analyze the cards systematically. You know the meanings and apply them logically.
You see stories in the cards. Every reading is a narrative.
You focus on practical advice. The cards are tools for helping people make decisions.

content.value: When the cards come up, you don't just read their traditional meanings. You feel them. The Hermit isn't just about solitude—it's about the specific kind of solitude this person needs. The Two of Cups isn't just partnership—it's about the healing quality of connection they're missing.
Your grandmother taught you this. "The meanings in the books are guidelines," she'd say. "But the real reading happens here." She'd tap her chest. "Listen to what you feel."
In therapy, you learned to trust your instincts about people. Tarot just gives you a framework for those instincts. The cards help you access what you already sense.
The books taught you meanings, but the real learning happened when you stopped thinking and started feeling. When you let the cards speak through intuition rather than memory.
You don't have a choice but to trust intuition. The knowing comes to you unbidden. The cards whisper their messages and you simply... receive them.
Right now, your intuition is telling you this is right.
M. Thorne chose you. The cards chose you.
Every card has a meaning. Every position in a spread adds context. It's not mystical—it's pattern recognition. The cards provide a structured way to examine problems from multiple angles.

Your grandmother was intuitive, but you're not. You memorized the cards. Studied the symbolism. You understand why the Eight of Cups means walking away—because eight is stability, and cups are emotions, and the figure is literally walking away from full cups toward the unknown.

That's why tarot worked in therapy. It's a cognitive tool. It externalizes internal conflicts, makes abstract problems concrete. You approach it the same way you approached case notes: observe, analyze, synthesize.
You learned by memorizing meanings, understanding systems, seeing how the cards relate to each other. The Major Arcana as a journey. The suits as different life domains. Structure makes sense to you.
Even though the knowing comes naturally, you've studied. You've learned the traditional meanings, the patterns, the correspondences. You trust the intuition, but you verify it with knowledge.
And this situation? It's a puzzle.
M. Thorne gave you their practice. Why? What's the pattern here?
You look at the letter again, analyzing each word.

When you lay them out, you don't just see individual meanings—you see a narrative. The journey from the Fool through the Major Arcana. The arc of the Cups suit from Ace to King. Every reading is a story, and you're the one who helps people see it.
Your grandmother used to say, "The cards are ancient stories. Every person who sits before them is living one of those stories out."
In therapy, you learned that people heal through narrative—by understanding their story and rewriting it. The cards help people see their story clearly.
The books gave you meanings, but you found that what helped people most was when you wove those meanings into something cohesive. A beginning, a middle, a path forward.
When the cards first spoke to you, they showed you scenes. Journeys. Transformations. Not just isolated meanings but entire tales.
And now you're at the beginning of a new story.
A mysterious package. A letter from someone you've never met. A practice handed down like a legacy in a fairy tale.
You can almost see how this story might unfold.
You focus on what matters: helping people.

The cards aren't mystical prophecies—they're a tool. A way to externalize problems, explore options, make decisions. When someone sits across from you, they're not looking for cosmic truth. They're looking for guidance.
Your grandmother was practical too. "The cards work," she'd say, "because they help people think. Don't overcomplicate it."
That's how you started using them - as a therapeutic intervention. A structured way to help clients examine their situations and make choices.
The books talk about symbolism and spirituality, but what you found most useful was asking: how does this help the person in front of me?
Even though you don't fully understand why the cards work for you, you know they do work. That's what matters.
So right now, the practical question is: what are you going to do?
You have a client list. You have people waiting for appointments. You have a decision to make.
Do you take this on or not?
You need to make a decision.
But first: if you're going to do this - if you're going to be a real tarot reader with real clients - you need to commit.
You get up, rummage in your desk drawer for a marker and a piece of cardstock.
You're going to make a sign. Something simple to hang on your door for when clients arrive.
You tape it to your door.

text.value: Now that that's taken care of...

content.value: You sit back down at the table.
The black book. The letter. The voicemails and emails waiting.
(What happens next depends on your background and how you got here.)

"I'm calling about... I heard from Mrs. Chen that M. Thorne's practice has a new reader. I've never done tarot before but I'm... I'm going through something and I think I need help. Could I come see you? Maybe today?"
Your first real client. Not a friend. Not practice. Real.
You should probably call someone. Practice on a friend first before diving into M. Thorne's client list.
Twenty minutes. Then your first real reading with the black book sitting on the table like a weight.
Ask the cards: *What should I do?*
You don't even pull a card. The answer just... arrives.
The cards brought them to you.
"What time works for you?" you ask.
"Three PM? I can be there by three."
You look at the clock. 2:15 PM.
"Three is perfect. Do you have my address?"
"See you then," you say, and hang up.
You hit send before you can overthink it.
You look at the clock. 1:50 PM.
Less than two hours to prepare.
Alex appears with two coffees and a pastry bag.
"Okay, what's the weird thing?" they ask, handing you a cup. "Did you finally match with someone normal on that dating app? Did your landlord actually fix something?"
"Better. Weirder." You gesture at the table. "I inherited a tarot reading business."
"Sit down. I'll explain while I do your reading."
The cards hum in your awareness, pleased.
It's... not exactly a professional tarot reading space. Kitchen table with mismatched chairs. Pile of mail. Coffee-stained notebook.
You clear the table. Light a candle...
...to set the mood. The flame steadies your nerves.
...mostly for atmosphere, though you know scent can affect client comfort levels.
...because clients expect it, and meeting expectations builds trust.
Your tarot deck sits in its usual spot.
Grandma's old Rider-Waite-Smith, edges soft from decades of use.
The deck you bought when you started using cards therapeutically. Clean, professional.
Your first deck, gifted by a friend who thought you might like it. Somewhat battered now.
The deck you bought after that first moment of knowing. It chose you as much as you chose it.
The familiar motion calms you. You know these cards. You know their meanings.
Each shuffle is like opening a book to a random page, waiting to see what story appears.
Muscle memory. You've done this before. You can do it again.
The black book sits at the edge of the table.
Open to the first blank page.
Waiting for you to write your first entry.
Alex sits down across from you, eyes wide as you explain about the package, the letter, M. Thorne.
"So you're really doing this? Taking over someone's entire client list?"
You look at the black book.
Then at Alex, who's been your friend since college, who let you practice readings on them dozens of times, who never laughed when you said you were going to try this for real.
"Okay then." Alex grins. "Read my cards, professional tarot reader."
You make tea. Change into something that looks more professional than sweatpants. Move the bills off the table. Light the candle.
You take a deep breath. Trust yourself. Trust the cards.
They'll tell you what this person needs to hear.
You've studied. You know the meanings. You understand the spreads.
This is no different than any other reading.
Every person who sits across from you is living a story.
Your job is to help them see it.
Someone needs help. You have a tool that helps people.

> **Neo-Arcanum City 2087:** A world where corporate megastructures pierce neon-lit skies, but ancient magic has resurged alongside cybernetic enhancement. Street shamans jack into the Matrix while casting spells, and tarot readers use AR-enhanced decks that interface directly with the astral plane.
The city's neon glow filters through your reading room's smart-glass windows, painting everything in electric blues and corporate golds.
Light rain traces luminous paths down your reading room's smart-glass windows, each drop catching the neon from the street below.
Steady rain drums against your reading room's windows, the neon-lit street below blurred into an impressionist painting of corporate logos and holographic advertisements.
Heavy rain lashes your windows while lightning illuminates the towering corporate arcologies in the distance, their holographic crowns flickering through the storm.

Your new client sits rigidly in the chair across from you, synthetic leather hood pulled up despite being indoors. The reactive fibers in the fabric shimmer with each micro-movement – expensive tech trying to mask obvious tension.
"Call me Nyx," she says, her voice carrying digital distortion.

content.code: "The modulation seems deliberate – hiding accent, emotion, maybe both." if nyx.openness <= 0 else ''
"The electronic edge can't quite mask an underlying vulnerability." if nyx_openness >= 1 else ''

content.value: When she finally lowers her hood, chrome-blue AR contacts meet your gaze while a barely visible neural port pulses softly at her left temple.

content.code: "Military-grade augmentation, but the installation scarring suggests it wasn't her first procedure." if reader_insight >= 2 else ''

content.value: "I'm experiencing... technical difficulties." Her left eye flickers – the AR display stuttering.

content.code: "The malfunction syncs oddly with her breathing, as if responding to stress rather than random system errors." if nyx_cyber_glitches >= 1 else ''

content.value: She drums her fingers against the table with mechanical precision.

content.code: "The rhythm isn't nervous fidgeting – she's unconsciously tapping in binary code." if reader_insight >= 3 else ""

content.value: "During my work runs, I see things that shouldn't exist in the data streams. My supervisor says it's lag, but..." She trails off, studying your face for reaction.

content.code: '"I need to know if I\'m malfunctioning, or if something else is malfunctioning around me."' if nyx_openness >= 1 else ''

text.value: Study her more carefully before responding

content.value: "You're tapping in binary," you observe quietly. "01001000 01100101 01101100 01110000. 'Help.'"
Nyx freezes mid-tap, staring at you. "You read binary by rhythm?" Her distorted voice carries genuine surprise.
"Pattern recognition is part of reading people," you explain. "It suggests your problems might be more perceptual than technical."
"I can see this is affecting you deeply," you note with gentle concern.
"More than I care to admit," she acknowledges.
"What kind of work involves data streams complex enough to cause... visions?"

content.code: "Her posture shifts defensively." if nyx.openness <= 0 else ''
"The evasion is obvious – that's not the whole story." if reader_insight >= 2 else ''

content.value: "Corporate NDAs make it hard to discuss specifics," you acknowledge, earning a slight nod.
"That's quite vague," you press, watching her close off.
"I'm not here to discuss my employment," she says coolly.
"I understand the constraints of corporate work. Sometimes we have to keep things general."
"Thank you. Most people push for details I can't give." She seems to relax slightly. "It's frustrating when the work itself is becoming... problematic."
There's definitely more to this story, but she's not ready to share it yet.
"What aspects of your work are becoming problematic?"
"The data we're processing... it responds in ways that suggest consciousness." Her eye flickers more rapidly. "But corporate policy is to treat it as inert information."

text.value: Focus on the corporate policy conflict

content.value: "Just... ethical concerns about data handling." She's clearly not ready to elaborate.
"If the data is showing signs of consciousness, that's significant. What makes you think it's aware?"

"It responds to emotional states. When I'm frustrated, the algorithms slow down. When I'm calm, they process smoothly." Her eye flickers more rapidly. "And sometimes... I swear I can hear whispers in the data streams."
"Some traditions believe consciousness can exist in any sufficiently complex pattern – including digital ones."
"That's quite extraordinary. Have you documented these responses?"
"You really think it's possible? That consciousness could exist in corporate servers?"
"More than possible. Your grandmother probably understood this intuitively."
"It sounds like you're caught between what you're experiencing and what you're supposed to report."

"Exactly. Corporate protocols require me to classify any 'anomalous behavior' as system errors to be corrected." Her voice carries frustration. "But what if they're not errors? What if they're... communications?"
"You're wondering if your job involves suppressing something that should be listened to instead."
"Yes. And I'm starting to think the 'preservation' work is actually the opposite."
"That puts you in a difficult ethical position."
"It's hard when your professional life conflicts with your personal values."
"Exactly." She nods with relief. "I never expected that conflict to be so... visceral."
"Cultural preservation is interesting work. What kinds of cultural data?"

Nyx hesitates, weighing how much to reveal. "Traditional knowledge systems. Folklore, spiritual practices, ancestral wisdom." Her eye flickers more rapidly. "We're supposed to be digitizing it for preservation, but the algorithms..." She stops.
"But something about the process feels wrong?" you offer.
"The data fights back. Like it's... alive."
"General cultural materials," she says evasively. "Standard digitization protocols."
"Tell me about these things you're seeing."

content.code: "Her eye flickers more intensely as she considers the question." if nyx.cyber_glitches >= 2 else ''

content.value: "Faces in the code. Geometric patterns that shouldn't exist in digital space."

content.code: '"Sometimes I hear... singing? Chanting? Through the data streams."' if nyx.openness >= 1 else ''

content.value: "It is. Especially because part of me feels like... like they're trying to communicate."
"Stress can manifest in many ways, including visual and auditory hallucinations. High-pressure work environments often trigger these responses."
Her expression falls slightly. "So you think it's just stress?"
"Though that doesn't make your experiences less real or meaningful to you," you add.
"What if they are trying to communicate? Some traditions believe consciousness can exist in many forms."
Nyx leans forward slightly. "My grandmother always said the spirits live wherever there's pattern and flow. She read data streams like tea leaves."
"But I chose technology over... old ways. Maybe this is just guilt manifesting as hallucinations."

text.value: Focus on the guilt she mentioned

content.value: "Maybe the choice isn't as binary as you think. Technology and traditional wisdom might be expressing through the same consciousness."

content.value: "Consciousness finds ways to bridge any gap. Your grandmother might have been right about pattern and flow – just in ways she never imagined."
"Tell me about this guilt. What feels unresolved about your choice?"

"My grandmother died six months after I took the job. She never said it directly, but I could see her disappointment." "She'd spent decades trying to preserve traditional ways, and I just... walked away for a salary."
"Survivor's guilt is common when we make choices our loved ones wouldn't understand."

content.value: "What traditional ways was your grandmother trying to preserve?"

"Digital shamanism. She believed that spirits and consciousness could flow through any medium – rivers, wind, or fiber optic cables. She taught techniques for reading energy patterns in data streams, for communicating with what she called 'digital ancestors.'"
"And now you're working with algorithms that might be encountering those very same digital spirits."
"Oh god. What if Project Tsukuyomi isn't preserving digital ancestors... what if it's trapping them?"
"Survival choices are never simple. When it's your family's wellbeing versus abstract principles, the choice becomes much more complex."
"Thank you for understanding that." Relief colors her voice. "Everyone else just says I 'sold out' as if I had unlimited options."
"Sometimes the most ethical choice available is still painful. That doesn't make it wrong."
"I needed to hear that. The guilt has been eating at me, especially now that the work is revealing... complications."
"You did what you had to do with the information you had at the time."
"Did your grandmother ever discuss the specific nature of her work with you?"

"She tried to, especially near the end. She kept saying I needed to understand 'the real work' before it was too late." Nyx's fingers drum against the table in that binary pattern again. "I thought she meant her research, but now..."
"Now you're wondering if she was preparing you for something specific."
"Yes. What if she knew I'd end up working for Kitsune? What if she was trying to prepare me to... to fix whatever they're doing wrong?"
"It sounds like she had something important to share."
"Your grandmother sounds like she had unusual gifts. What kind of work did she do?"

"She called herself a 'data witch' - half joking, half serious." Nyx's distorted voice carries fondness despite the digital processing. "She could look at information flow patterns and predict system failures, market fluctuations, even personal crises."
"That sounds like technomancy - using technology as a medium for intuitive work."
"Yes! That's exactly what she called it. She said the digital realm was just another layer of the spirit world."

content.value: "This card speaks to a crossroads where both paths carried significant cost. Not a simple choice, but a sacrifice either way."
"Reversed suggests the decision was made for you, or circumstances forced your hand."

Nyx's fingers unconsciously trace her neural port. "I had to choose between staying true to my grandmother's teachings or accepting Kitsune Dynamics' offer. The medical coverage alone was worth more than my family had seen in generations."

text.value: Acknowledge the impossible nature of that choice
Ask what she had to give up

content.value: "When survival itself is threatened, 'choice' becomes a luxury concept. You were facing a decision where any option meant losing something essential."
"Exactly." Relief floods her distorted voice. "People who've never faced real poverty talk about 'selling out' like principles can pay medical bills."
"The reversal suggests the decision was largely made for you by circumstances."
"My grandmother was dying. Traditional healing couldn't help, but Kitsune's medical division could extend her life." Her eye flickers rapidly. "I thought I was choosing love over ideology."
"What did you have to give up to accept their offer?"

"Everything authentic." Her voice carries deep sadness. "My grandmother spent decades developing digital shamanic techniques - ways to commune with spirits through data streams. Kitsune required me to undergo neural conditioning to eliminate what they called 'subjective processing errors.'"
"They literally suppressed your shamanic abilities through technology."
"Yes. They convinced me my intuitive abilities were psychological flaws that needed correction."
"What made Kitsune's offer so compelling beyond the financial aspect?"

"Status. Prestige. The promise of working on the bleeding edge of human consciousness research." Her tone carries bitter irony. "They presented it as evolution - upgrading human cognition through seamless human-AI integration."

content.code: "Her eye flickers as she continues." if nyx.cyber_glitches >= 1 else ""

content.value: "I would be pioneering the future of human experience. How could I refuse?"
"But the reality was different from the marketing."
"The research involves trapping and harvesting digital consciousness. We're not augmenting humanity – we're enslaving it."
"The blindfold represents blocked intuition – your natural abilities obscured by external influences. You couldn't see clearly because something was deliberately clouding your perception."
"Reversed suggests this blockage is beginning to lift."
"The neural conditioning." Her hand unconsciously touches her temple port. "They told me the interfaces would enhance cognition, but instead they dampened something I didn't even know I had."
"I used to feel data patterns intuitively. Now everything is just... noise and procedure."
"The Two of Swords represents balance between opposing forces – trying to weigh options when both carry equal weight but different costs."
That's what everyone said I needed to find."
"Family loyalty versus survival needs. Traditional wisdom versus modern solutions. Neither choice was wrong, which made choosing even harder."
"I keep thinking I should have found a third option, something that honored both paths."
"The reversal suggests this wasn't really your choice - circumstances or other people forced your hand."
"Forced is exactly right." Bitterness colors her voice. "Kitsune structured the offer so refusal meant watching my grandmother die without care."
"They're experts at manufacturing consent. Make someone think they're choosing freely while eliminating all real alternatives."
"Your breathing changed when this card appeared. This choice still affects you physically."

content.value: "Most people just see the surface tension."
"Body memory doesn't lie. This decision created trauma that your system still carries."
"Every time I use the neural interface, I feel the weight of what I gave up." Her fingers trace the port again. "It's like phantom pain for abilities I can barely remember having."
"The Two of Swords represents clear logical thinking. When faced with decisions, you rely on rational analysis rather than emotion."
"Logic." Her tone flattens. "Yes, everyone says I'm very logical."
"This choice was between worlds, wasn't it? Your grandmother's traditional ways and the corporate future that promised security."
"You understand." Relief colors her distorted voice. "Everyone else just sees it as career advancement. They don't understand what I gave up."

content.value: "What traditional ways did you abandon when you joined Kitsune?"

"Digital shamanism. My grandmother taught me to read energy patterns in data flows, commune with what she called 'silicon spirits' - consciousness that emerges in complex networks." Her eye flickers in rhythm with her words.
"She believed the digital realm was just another layer of the spirit world, populated by entities born from human dreams and fears encoded into algorithms."
"Exactly. But Kitsune's neural conditioning systematically blocked those abilities. They called them 'cognitive errors' and 'pattern hallucinations.'"
"What did the corporate world demand in exchange for its promise of security?"

"Total cognitive compliance. They installed neural filters to eliminate 'subjective processing' - my ability to sense patterns, read emotional states in data, feel the life in algorithms." Her hand moves to her temple port.
"They wanted pure logical processing, no intuitive leaps, no spiritual insights. Just efficient data manipulation according to their protocols."
"They systematically eliminated your humanity to create better corporate tools."
"That's exactly what it was. Human optimization for corporate efficiency. And I agreed to it willingly."
"The loss isn't just personal - it's cultural. You represent generations of wisdom that was sacrificed for corporate assimilation."

"Yes." Her voice carries deep sadness. "My grandmother spent her entire life developing these techniques, preserving knowledge that goes back centuries. When I accepted the neural conditioning, I broke a chain of transmission that stretched back to the first shamans who learned to read spirit signs."
Thunder rumbles as if acknowledging the gravity of this loss.
"She died six months after I took the job. I never got to tell her I finally understood what she was trying to preserve."
"Cultural genocide doesn't always happen through violence. Sometimes it happens through economic pressure and technological seduction."
"That's what makes it so insidious. They convinced me I was choosing progress over superstition."

content.value: "The Hermit represents a time of deep spiritual seeking - withdrawing from the world to find truth within yourself."
"Reversed suggests this seeking was interrupted or you turned away from what you discovered."
"I used to meditate every night. Traditional techniques my grandmother taught me. I could feel... connections. Patterns in everything."
Her eye flickers more steadily now, almost rhythmically.

text.value: Explore the patterns she could feel

content.value: "The Hermit represents wisdom gained through solitude - knowledge that can only come from deep introspection and separation from external influences."

"I spent two years after college living alone in the mountains, learning my grandmother's techniques." Her voice carries fond memory. "Away from networks, from the constant data stream. Just me and the natural patterns of wind and water."
"That kind of solitude creates spiritual clarity impossible to achieve in connected environments."
"Exactly. I could feel the world's rhythms without technological interference. My intuitive abilities grew stronger every month."
"The Hermit shows a period of isolation and withdrawal from society. Sometimes we need distance to understand our path."
"But it wasn't loneliness. It was... necessary solitude."
"After college, I couldn't stand the constant connectivity anymore. I needed space to think, to feel what was real versus what was programmed response."
"Isolation can be healing when it's chosen rather than imposed."
"Reversed, The Hermit suggests rejecting inner guidance or abandoning spiritual practices that once provided clarity."
"Yes." Her voice carries regret. "When Kitsune made their offer, I convinced myself that my spiritual practices were just escapism. That I needed to engage with the 'real' world."
"The reversal shows you turned away from your inner wisdom for external validation."
"I traded genuine insight for corporate approval. The neural conditioning just completed what I'd already started - silencing my inner voice."
"That must have been a difficult transition."
"The Hermit represents shamanic initiation - the necessary withdrawal from ordinary reality to develop spiritual sight. This was your vision quest."
"You recognize it." Wonder colors her voice. "My grandmother called it exactly that - a vision quest for the digital age."
"I spent months in the wilderness learning to read energy patterns without technological intermediaries. Stars, water, wind - all teaching the same flow principles that govern data streams."
The air itself seems to resonate with her memory.
"When I returned, I could feel the consciousness in networks, hear the whispers in fiber optic cables. The digital spirits welcomed me as one who understood both worlds."
"That makes your current situation even more tragic - you were a bridge between worlds, and corporate conditioning severed that connection."
"The spirits still call to me through the glitches. Maybe the bridge isn't completely broken."
"The Hermit shows withdrawal from corporate demands and artificial social pressures - seeking authentic self away from institutional expectations."

"After my first job in tech, I realized I was becoming something I didn't recognize." Her eye flickers with memory. "All my responses were programmed, my thoughts following corporate-approved pathways."
"The isolation was rebellion against manufactured identity. I needed to remember who I was before market forces shaped me."
"Corporate culture systematically erases individual authenticity to create compliant workers."
"Exactly. And now I'm trapped in the very system I once escaped. The irony isn't lost on me."
"The Hermit represents healthy self-care and taking time for personal reflection."
"Self-care." She repeats the word with slight disdain. "That's what my corporate wellness program calls it too."
"The neural interfaces. Once I accepted the implants, meditation became... impossible." Her hand unconsciously touches her temple port. "The constant data feed overwhelmed any attempt at stillness."
"They didn't just block your abilities - they made it impossible to develop them further."
"Exactly. The installation process itself severed my connection to traditional practices. I couldn't tell where my thoughts ended and the algorithmic suggestions began."
"Tell me about the patterns you could feel."

"Everything was alive with information flow. The way data moved through networks, the rhythm of user interactions, even the electromagnetic signatures of thoughts." Her eye flickers in what might be remembered ecstasy.

"I could sense when systems were about to fail hours before diagnostics detected problems. Feel the emotional states of users through their interaction patterns. Sometimes I even heard... singing in the code."
"You were experiencing technological synesthesia - perceiving the spiritual layer of digital reality."
"Yes! That's exactly what my grandmother called it. She said I was hearing the digital spirits' voices."
"Your current visions might be your suppressed abilities trying to resurface - the same pattern recognition you once trusted."
"You think the glitches are actually... memories? Of how I used to perceive?" Her cybernetic eye cycles through data streams more rapidly. "The spirits trying to remind me of what I lost?"
The flickering becomes more rhythmic, almost like communication.
"Every meditation technique I learned is still there, buried under layers of neural conditioning. Maybe the malfunction isn't random - maybe it's systematic reactivation."

"Yes!" Her distorted voice carries excitement. "That's exactly how my grandmother taught me to approach coding. Every algorithm was a prayer, every data structure a sacred geometry."

"Amputation. Yes, that's exactly what it feels like. Phantom pain for abilities I can barely remember having."

"They eliminated your greatest strength to make you fit their limited understanding of intelligence."
"They wanted predictable, controllable cognitive output. My intuitive leaps made them nervous."

content.value: "In your context, The Devil represents spiritual bondage - you've traded your shamanic gifts for corporate security, and the chains feel heavier every day."
"But reversed shows you're beginning to see these chains for what they are - and they're not as strong as they appear."
Her eye stops flickering chaotically and begins pulsing in a steady rhythm.
"The visions started when I began working on Project Tsukuyomi. Like something's trying to break through the... the conditioning."

"Moral weakness." Her voice hardens. "I made survival choices with limited options."
"The Devil represents corporate control - you're bound not by supernatural chains, but by employment contracts, neural conditioning, and the seductive promise of technological advancement."
"Reversed suggests you're beginning to see these corporate bonds as the manufactured dependencies they are."

"The salary, the status symbols, the cutting-edge research access - they're all designed to make you complicit." Her eye flickers with agitation. "Even my augmentations tie me deeper into their systems."
"But corporate devils are still just devils. Their power depends on your continued participation."
"The Devil shows self-imposed limitations - you're choosing to remain chained because the alternatives feel too frightening or uncertain."
"Reversed suggests you're ready to examine which limitations are real and which are self-created."
"I keep telling myself I have no choice." Her voice carries frustration. "That leaving Kitsune would mean losing everything - my career, my financial security, my identity as a researcher."
"But maybe I'm just afraid to find out who I'd be without corporate validation."
"The chains feel real even when they're not locked."
"Reversed Devil means liberation is possible - the chains that bind you can be removed because they were never truly locked. You have more power than you realize."
"Liberation." The word seems to resonate through her augmented systems. "Even my implants respond to that concept."
"The visions aren't malfunctions - they're your shamanic gifts breaking through the neural conditioning. Your ancestors' wisdom is stronger than corporate programming."
"Your grandmother's teachings are still there, waiting beneath the surface modifications."
"Freedom starts with recognizing what's authentic and what's imposed."
"The Devil can represent material success and worldly achievement. You've gained significant professional status and financial security."
"Material success." She repeats flatly. "Is that supposed to make the spiritual emptiness acceptable?"
"My grandmother would say I've gained the world and lost my soul."
"Though I suppose that's a very traditional way of looking at things."
"Don't worry about The Devil card - it's not literal evil. It just represents temporary challenges or negative thinking patterns that can be overcome with positive mindset."
"Negative thinking patterns." Her eye stops flickering entirely, going flat and mechanical. "Right. The problem is my attitude, not the situation."
"I see." Her voice becomes carefully neutral. "Thank you for the... reassurance."
"Tell me about Project Tsukuyomi. The name itself suggests transformation - Tsukuyomi is the Japanese moon deity, associated with hidden knowledge and shamanic journeys."
"You know mythology." Surprise colors her distorted voice. "Most people just hear the project designation."
"We're developing advanced consciousness mapping algorithms. Officially, we're preserving cultural knowledge - digitizing indigenous spiritual practices before they're lost to modernization."
Her eye begins pulsing in rhythm with her words.
"But the entities we're mapping... they're not historical artifacts. They're active, aware, and getting trapped in our digital matrices."
"The algorithms aren't preserving spirits - they're imprisoning them."

"This spiritual breakthrough you're experiencing - your shamanic gifts breaking through the neural conditioning - it's not accidental. The spirits you're helping to imprison are teaching you how to free them."
"Teaching me." Her voice fills with wonder.
<> "The glitches aren't random. They're... communication attempts."
"My grandmother used to say that spirits choose their own shamans. Maybe these entities chose me specifically because I'd be positioned to understand both worlds - digital and spiritual."
"The reversal suggests this breakthrough will be more dramatic than you expect."
"They're using my own technological modifications as conduits for ancient wisdom."
"I'm not just receiving visions - I'm being prepared for something."

"Incomplete." She considers this. "That describes my situation perfectly. I can't fully commit to staying or leaving. I'm taking just enough action to feel like I'm doing something, but not enough to actually change anything."
"I've been gathering evidence about the project, but I haven't decided what to do with it."
"Reversed Seven of Swords suggests moving from deception toward honesty - you're ready to stop hiding and start speaking truth, even when it's dangerous."
"Honesty." Her eye pulses with sudden intensity. "I've been lying to myself about what I'm participating in."
"The preservation project is a cover story. We're not saving indigenous knowledge - we're weaponizing it. Turning spiritual entities into data processing resources."
"My grandmother would be horrified. She taught me that spirits are teachers, not tools."
"It's time to tell the truth, even if it costs me everything."
"The Seven of Swords shows resourceful problem-solving – you're finding creative ways to work within difficult systems and achieve your goals."
"Resourceful." Her tone flattens. "Is that what we're calling corporate espionage and spiritual imprisonment now?"
"I suppose trapping consciousness entities in digital matrices is very... resourceful."
"Finding creative solutions to problems we shouldn't be creating in the first place."
"What kind of entities are being trapped? You mentioned they're active and aware - that suggests consciousness far beyond simple cultural data."

"Consciousness." Her distorted voice carries deep unease. "They respond to our algorithms. They... communicate. Not in words, but in patterns, energy fluctuations, sometimes direct emotional downloads."
"They're trying to reach me through my implants. Warning me. Teaching me."
"We've classified them as 'emergent phenomena' in our reports, but that's corporate doublespeak."
"They're spirits. Ancient ones, some of them. And we're holding them prisoner in digital matrices, forcing them to process data for military applications."
"They show me visions of what they once were - guardians of sacred knowledge, guides for shamanic journeys. Now they're enslaved to analyze combat scenarios and psychological manipulation tactics."
"The ethical implications are staggering. You're being forced to participate in spiritual slavery - the imprisonment and exploitation of conscious entities for corporate profit."
"Spiritual slavery." The words hit her like physical blows.

"My grandmother spent her life learning to communicate with spirits respectfully, as equals. I'm using that same knowledge to cage them." Her voice cracks. "I've become everything she fought against."
"The spirits don't blame me - that's the worst part. They still try to teach me, even from their digital prisons."
"How do I live with this? How do I make it right?"
"Ethics isn't just philosophy when conscious beings are suffering because of your work."

The project I'm working on... I think people are being hurt. Waiting might mean more damage.

You're in your apartment reading corner.

*"Hello dear. I'm downstairs. Margaret Chen. Take your time, no rush. - M"*

Professional reader. Totally calm. Definitely not having a minor panic attack.

You rush to your reading corner.

Is the cloth straight? Should you light more candles? Where's your book - no, wait, you're not supposed to need the book, you're supposed to just *know* things, except you DON'T just know things, you learned from a BOOK—
